awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Transitioning Learners to Calculus in Community Colleges (TLC3): Advancing Strategies for Success in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
Improving student outcomes in mathematics courses in community colleges is important in meeting the nation's demand for college graduates in STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics). Entitled "Transitioning Learners to Calculus in Community Colleges" (TLC3), the project will gather a team of higher education researchers, mathematicians, and mathematics educators to transform institutional approaches to identifying and remedying barriers that impede student progress to and through Calculus II in community colleges. A significant impact of TLC3 will involve supporting instructional improvements aimed at increasing the success of historically undeserved students, particularly underrepresented racial minority (URM) students, thus contributing ultimately to the diversity of the nation's STEM workforce. 

The broader goal of TLC3 is to build and test theoretical models that predict STEM URM student success in the Developmental to Pre-calculus to Calculus II (DPC2) sequence, based on programs, structures, and instructional strategies in successful programs. The project uses a mixed-methods approach, including a census survey of 948 community colleges and case studies focused on minority-serving institutions. The models will inform the development of a change tool (i.e., the institutional self-assessment), that examines institutional readiness to facilitate successful outcomes for URM students in the DPC2 sequence. Five institutions selected from a TLC3 networked community (with a minimum of 50 institutions) will test the models and self-assessment tool. The institutional self-assessment tool will help identify a professional development approach that departments and institutions can use to remedy barriers that inhibit student success in the DPC2 sequence. This project is supported by NSF's Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program (IUSE) and the EHR Core Research (ECR) Program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field.

por.por_cntn:
Transitioning Learners to Calculus in Community Colleges (TLC3)  is an Institutional and Community Transformation Development and Implementation project aimed at transforming institutional approaches to support the matriculation of STEM majors into and through Calculus II in community colleges. This project gives special focus on historically underrepresented minorities (URM) such as African American, Latinx, Southeast Asian, and Native American students. It continues the work of the National Study of Calculus (NSF DRL REESE #0910240) and focuses on the  Developmental Mathematics to Precalculus and Calculus II (DPC2) sequence. The TLC3 research team surveyed Community College Mathematics Chairs and studied student progression towards higher-level mathematics required for STEM with the goal of building and testing theoretical models that predict the success of URM students in the DPC2 sequence.

A major outcome of this study was the development of the TLC3 Institutional Self-Assessment Tool (ISAT) which includes a validated set of practices identified by the research team as having the potential to influence the success of URM students in the DPC2 sequence. The practices are grouped into five domains: mathematics placement, STEM mathematics courses, instruction (both mathematical and relational), student support, and institutional responsibility. The tool is designed to be respectful of the context of the college, taking into account the student population and the mission, history, culture, climate, and resources, and it can be used by individuals or collective stakeholders to self-assess their implementation of the practices and identify next steps to increase URM success. 

 

The intellectual merit of the TLC3 project was further strengthened by the interdisciplinary make-up of the research team, consisting of mathematicians, mathematics educators, higher education researchers, graduate students, and project evaluators. The varied backgrounds and insights of these professionals were key to data gathering, analysis and the recognition of any particular issues faced by URM students navigating the DPC2 sequence. Moreover, the project team utilized the diversity of their perspectives to create a comprehensive set of equity practices for promoting URM success. The dissemination plan leveraged strategic partnerships as well as the research team's diversity to ensure the findings were presented and understood in a manner that could be easily integrated into practice and existing policies. All of this was done with the ultimate goal of promoting greater diversity in the STEM workforce in the United States. 


 

 



 

 


Last Modified: 01/09/2023
Modified by: Helen E Burn
